newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Palestinians get life in murder of Israeli driver.
newsitem.headline: Palestinians get life in murder of Israeli driver.

text.p: A Palestinian court sentenced two Palestinians to life in jail on Saturday for the murder of an Israeli taxi driver just hours after his battered body was found in a well in the West Bank town of Jericho.
Jericho security court chief Ummayyad Tahboub said two men were given a life sentence with hard labour and a third, aged 17, was sentenced to 15 years in prison.
The killing was said to be not politically motivated.

Israeli police praised the "full security cooperation" from their Palestinian counterparts which led to the swift justice meted out to the three men for the murder of 45-year-old Shmuel Ben-Baruch, who went missing on Thursday night.
The two men sentenced to life were named as Abdel Nasser Mohammad Rizeq, 20, and Ala Jibril al-Damanhouri, 19. The 17-year-old was named as Iyad Mohyammad Ahmad Abu Shabab.

Ben-Baruch's body was found in the five-metre (17-feet) deep well at 1:30 a.m. (2230 gmt) on Saturday. Palestinian police said he had been smashed in the head with a stone and stabbed in the neck with a screwdriver.
The Jerusalem-based driver's bloodstained taxi had been found earlier in a dry riverbed in Aqabat Jabr refugee camp on the outskirts of Jericho.
Israeli police said the Mercedes taxi had been sold for 7,000 shekels ($2,000) to a man who used the riverbed as a storehouse for stolen vehicles.

"In this case I must say there is very good cooperation in the field despite the tensions between the (Palestinian) Authority and the (Israeli) state," Israel's Internal Security Minister Avigdor Kahalani told Israel Radio.
"In this instance it seems to me it is easier to cooperate because here we are talking about -- as it appears now -- car thieves who were motivated by money," he said.
Palestinian police said the three convicted men did not belong to any political organisation.
Israeli-Palestinian tension has been running high since a double suicide bombing killed 16 people, including the attackers, at a market in Jerusalem on July 30.
U.S. envoy Dennis Ross shuttled between Israeli and Palestinian leaders earlier this week in an effort to restore security cooperation and crack down on militants after the bombing.

Israel has imposed a closure on the West Bank and Gaza Strip, barring tens of thousands of Palestinians from entering the Jewish state. Kahalani said Ben-Baruch's abduction and murder proved the closure was not hermetic.
